title: 110_hr662
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Latin Americans of Japanese Descent Act". The purpose of the Act is to establish findings and a purpose for the commission. During World War II, the United States expanded its internment program to include Latin Americans of Japanese descent, detaining approximately 2,300 individuals for the purpose of exchanging them for American citizens held by Axis countries. During World War II, Latin Americans of Japanese descent were detained by the Department of State in internment camps operated by the Immigration and Naturalization Service from 1941 through 1948. Individuals were arrested without a warrant, hearing, or indictment by local police and sent to the United States for internment. Passports of these individuals were routinely confiscated before arrival in the United States, and visas were refused by United States consuls in Latin American countries. Approximately 2,300 men, women, and children of Japanese descent from Latin America were detained in internment camps in the United States during World War II. They were considered illegal entrants and subject to deportation, with some being deported to Axis countries for prisoner exchanges. The Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians studied Federal actions related to detaining and interning civilians of enemy nationality, including those of Japanese descent. The program of interning Latin Americans of Japanese descent was not conducted under Executive Order 9066, but it is important to examine this extraordinary program for a complete account of Federal actions. The purpose of the Act is to establish a Commission to investigate the relocation, internment, and deportation of Latin Americans of Japanese descent from 1941 to 1948, recommend remedies based on findings, and address the group not covered by the Civil Liberties Act of 1988. Establishment of the Commission to investigate the relocation, internment, and deportation of Latin Americans of Japanese descent from 1941 to 1948. The Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Latin Americans of Japanese descent is established with 9 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate within 60 days of enactment of the Act. Members serve for a specified period and vacancies are filled accordingly. The Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Latin Americans of Japanese descent is established with 9 members appointed for life. Vacancies do not affect powers and are filled as per original appointment. Meetings are called by the President within specific timelines. A quorum of five members is required, and the Commission elects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. The Commission elects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members, who serve for the life of the Commission. The Commission elects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members, who serve for the life of the Commission. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall extend the study to investigate the relocation, internment, and deportation of Latin Americans of Japanese descent by the United States from December 1941 to February 1948, reviewing directives of the Armed Forces and Department of State. The Commission will investigate the relocation, internment, and deportation of Latin Americans of Japanese descent by the United States during 1941-1948. A report with findings and recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The Commission has powers to investigate the relocation, internment, and deportation of Latin Americans of Japanese descent by the United States during 1941-1948. The Commission has the authority to conduct public hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to gather evidence for investigating the relocation, internment, and deportation of Latin Americans of Japanese descent by the United States during 1941-1948. The Commission, chaired by the Chairperson, can issue subpoenas for testimony and evidence. Failure to comply may result in a court order for appearance or production of evidence, punishable as contempt. Witness allowances and fees are governed by Section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. The Commission can obtain information from federal agencies as needed. It is also authorized to use postal services like other government departments. Witness allowances and fees are paid from Commission funds. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on the level IV of the Executive Schedule for their duties. Officers or employees of the US government will not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided to members while away from home. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws. Compensation for personnel can be determined by the Chairperson, not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can detail Federal Government employees without reimbursement, procure temporary services, and enter into agreements for financial and administrative services. The Commission can enter into contracts with various entities for research, surveys, reports, and other necessary activities. SEC. 7. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report to Congress under section 4(b).

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Authorized appropriations for this Act will be available without fiscal year limitation.
